text: Thanks for the update.  Yes, I have had really good experiences with the core microsoft developers since reaching out to them.  Jupyter developers less so... I have a bad feeling about jupyter as a software project (the `.ipynb` format isn't going anywhere, but the python jupyer code/kernel/jupyterlab/etc. aren't needed after everyone else implements it and eventually finds better file formats).  I just have a hard time seeing why anyone would use jupyterlab after vscode and github codespaces is up and urnning with all these features.  And the clean typescript setup means that nobody needs to battle conda just to show notebooks.

elements.text: Thanks for the update.  Yes, I have had really good experiences with the core microsoft developers since reaching out to them.  Jupyter developers less so... I have a bad feeling about jupyter as a software project (the

text: Yeah, to be honest, I don't see a bright future for Jupyter Lab... But hey, who knows :slightly_smiling_face: I'm really curios about the pricing for codespaces, and in particular whether there will be some way for say universities to easily provide "codespace minutes" to students.

elements.text: Yeah, to be honest, I don't see a bright future for Jupyter Lab... But hey, who knows
I'm really curios about the pricing for codespaces, and in particular whether there will be some way for say universities to easily provide "codespace minutes" to students.

text: From a technical point of view, I think the codespaces, VS Code Jupyter story is just so much better, but I don't yet see how I could use it in a class, if individual students would have to pay by the minute for their use of codespaces...

elements.text: From a technical point of view, I think the codespaces, VS Code Jupyter story is just so much better, but I don't yet see how I could use it in a class, if individual students would have to pay by the minute for their use of codespaces...

text: Yeah, that doesn't work at all for sure.

elements.text: Yeah, that doesn't work at all for sure.

text: But maybe they'll just put some free allocation into their existing education offerings.

elements.text: But maybe they'll just put some free allocation into their existing education offerings.

text: We shall see what microsoft has up their sleaves.  More importnatly, thgouh, I don't think anything stopping othres from hosting the devcontainer and vscode in a browser.  I think others may even have already done  it?

text: Has berkely talked to microsoft about this, or is binder/jupyterhub just too entrenched to even start those converstations?

elements.text: Has berkely talked to microsoft about this, or is binder/jupyterhub just too entrenched to even start those converstations?

text: There are privacy legislation issues as well for Canada (and I would expect germany) about where data can be stored.  YOu can get away with that stuff for a small opt-in class, but for the bigger ones it is a real issue.  I think the universities would be willing to pay a license for local hosting of this stuff in their countries if it wasn't exhorbitant.

text: I'm not aware of any discussions from Berkeley's side with MS about this... I do think there is a branch on the <http://mybinder.org|mybinder.org> side of things that hosts VS Code, but I think it is not really kept up-to-date...

text: Definetely.  There is no technical reason why it shouldn't.  Anyways, fingers crossed that this stuff all works out.  Thanks again for dealing with all of my pestering and tree-shaking.

text: The thing that seems to be missing is the analogy to nbgitpuller's launching a particular page in the codespaces.  With that, you could then link to a particular page in a repo (which is a notebook or `.jl` file or whatever) and launch it directly.  But I think we can live wihtout it for teaching
